title: One of Connecticut’s ‘Grand Old Ladies’ Will Ask $6.7 Million
text:
The eight-bedroom, four-bathroom Darien, Connecticut, home once owned by former Time Inc. chairman Andrew Heiskell and his wife, civic leader Marian Sulzberger Heiskell, is set to hit the market on Monday for $6.7 million.



Built on Long Neck Point in 1915, the home has one of the most desirable addresses in Darien, according to listing agent Doug Milne of Houlihan Lawrence.



“Long Neck Point is a one-mile stretch of land that sticks like a finger into the middle of the Long Island Sound,” he said. “It’s one of the few places on both sides with water views from either the front or the back of the house.”



More: Nestled in a Wealthy Denver Suburb, This 1952 French Country-Style House Has a ‘Hollywood-Esque’ Interior

It also sits on a bluff, which helps protect the property from the water around it.



“People are very sensitive today about waterfront—they love it, but they are also afraid of hurricanes,” according to Mr. Milne. “This home sits 20-plus feet above the flood zone.”



Additionally, it’s one of a handful of properties in the area with its own beach, he pointed out. Mature, well-maintained gardens surround the home, and there’s also an outdoor pool.



The home itself is one of the “grand old ladies of Darien,” Mr. Milne said, adding that the family owned it for more than 70 years. Mr. Milne would often see Sulzberger Heiskell looking out onto the water from its windows. In March she died at the age of 100.



Sulzberger Heiskell spent a lifetime doing good works in and around New York City, according to her obituary in The New York Times. She was also a member of the Sulzberger family, which controls the Times. During her life, she led efforts to restore the city’s theaters on 42nd Street, and was an advocate for local, state and national parks, among other projects.



She married Heiskell in 1965. He was chairman of Time Inc. from 1960 to 1980. During his time there, Sulzberger Heiskell came up with the idea for People magazine, according to People.com. She thought the one-page “People” segment in Time could be a standalone magazine.



More: Al Capone’s New Jersey Hideaway Listed for $1.75 Million

After Heiskell retired from Time in 1980, he lent his time and effort to projects like preserving the New York Public Library and Bryant Park.



The home was originally used in the summer by the Heiskells, and later as a more permanent residence. In fact, Heiskell died there in 2003, according to his New York Times obituary. At the time of his death, he had already transferred ownership to the president and fellows of Harvard College. The college has owned it since 1994, according to property records.



Mr. Heiskell was not an alum, but was elected to the Harvard Board of Overseers and, later, spent 10 years on the Harvard Corporation, one of the university's governing boards, according to his obit. Representatives from the college were not immediately available for comment.



The house has had few updates since the 1990s, but has many of the features one would expect in a home dating from 1915, including a grand entrance hall, formal living room and spacious dining room. The living space covers three floors, with smaller rooms on the top floor that was once occupied by staff.



The house also has an elevator, “which is quite unusual,” according to Mr. Milne.

Mr. Milne explained the sellers are “not emotional” about the deal. To that end, it’s “very attractively priced.”



“From a discerning buyer’s point of view, who is looking for location, and either wants to custom-design their own compound...or restore one of the grand old ladies, it’s affordable to do either one,” Mr. Milne said. “And people that know Darien will definitely like this address.”
